text: Cognitive-Chair : AI based advanced Brain Sensing Wheelchair for Paraplegic/Quadriplegic people Kshitij Joshi
University Vadodara, India kshitijjoshi017@gmail.com Abhilasha Vyas CloudThat Vadodara, India abhilasha.cs27@gmail.com Pujan Soni
University Vadodara, India poojansoni57@gmail.com Rudra Joshi

University Vadodara, India rudrajoshi.cs@gmail.com Smit Joshi Babaria Institute of Technology Vadodara, India smitjoshi255@gmail.com Abstract— As of now, there exist manual wheelchairs just as electric wheelchairs constrained by the little joysticks, however they have their own limitations. They are confined to simply paraplegic people. Along these lines, for Quadriplegic individuals, this model miserably fails. Advancements in innovation lead us to another approach to control wheelchairs ; utilising brain signals of an individual. With the assistance of a similar strategy, We propose a system wherein the individual on a wheelchair will be given a keen headband to control the wheelchair based on neural signals or brain waves emitted from the brain utilising technologies like Brain-Computer Interface(BCI), Electrooculography (EOG) and Electroencephalography (EEG). Subsequent to applying these technologies on a small wheelchair model, we have gotten incredible accuracy of the neural-signals . Thus the results are quite astonishing. Apart from this, in future aspects considering the safety of passengers, if anything obstructing the way of the wheelchair comes too close; causing the person to lose their concentration, the wheelchair will sense the obstacle and will apply brakes immediately. Keywords— Artificial Intelligence, Internet of Things, Brain Sensing Technology, Brain Computer Interface, Smart Wheelchair, Neural Signals, Electrooculography (EOG), Electroencephalography (EEG). I.

WHO estimates that about 15 percent of the world's population has one or more disabilities, and that between 2 to 4 percent of those people have difficulty working. The global prevalence of disability is higher than previous WHO estimates from the 1970s, which put the rate at around 10%. [1]. In order to get around and get from one place to another , people with these disabilities always need some assistance. Wheelchairs have been in daily use for Paraplegic and Quadriplegic people since the dawn of technology . The development of wheelchairs has made it easier for people with disabilities to cope with their situation. Assistance or any external effort is always required to move when using the first generation of wheelchairs that were manually operated. An electric wheelchair was also developed in order to eliminate the need for external effort or other assistance but it has its own drawbacks. EEG (Electroencephalography) and EOG (Electrooculography) are two newly known technologies used to control the wheelchair by a paraplegic/quadiplegic person's brain and movements of eyes. Most of the external work would be eliminated if this system were introduced to society . A. Background 1. BCI - Brain computer interface is one of the most promising and increasingly popular technologies for assisting and enhancing communication/control for motor paralysis (e.g., paraplegia or quadriplegia)

be eliminated if this system were introduced to society . A. Background 1. BCI - Brain computer interface is one of the most promising and increasingly popular technologies for assisting and enhancing communication/control for motor paralysis (e.g., paraplegia or quadriplegia) due to stroke, spinal cord injury , cerebral palsy , and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) [2].

Brain-Computer Interface or Brain-Machine Interface or Direct Neural Interface is a technology which allows users to communicate with machines or any external devices using the brain signals rather than brains normal output pathways of peripheral nerves and muscles. Basically it gives humans the ability to directly control machines effortlessly . A BCI system is made up of three

electrodes that record electric, magnetic, or metabolic brain activity; a processing pipeline that interprets those signals, extracts relevant features, decodes patterns of interest, and outputs commands; and a computer or external device that acts on the generated commands [49]. Invasive, non-invasive, and semi-invasive brain computer interfaces (BCIs) are the three types of BCIs. [3]. a. Invasive - Microelectrodes are inserted into the brain and used to measure the activity of a single neuron in this approach. b. Non-Invasive - The microelectrodes are attached to the exposed surface of the brain in this method (ECoG). c. Semi-invasive - Sensors are put on the scalp to monitor the electrical potentials produced by the brain (EEG) or the magnetic field created by the brain (MEG). 2. Electroencephalography (EEG) - This device can measure brain activity by monitoring brain activity and the way distinct brain signals are converted into commands that drive an effector . The brain's cells use electrical signals to communicate with one another . The electrical activity of the brain, often known as brain waves, is measured by EEG . Gamma, Beta, Alpha, Theta, and Delta are the five main brainwave frequencies in Electroencephalography [44, 50]. a. Gamma Waves - Gamma waves are linked to the acquisition of new information in the brain. b. Beta Waves - Beta waves are frequently

Beta, Alpha, Theta, and Delta are the five main brainwave frequencies in Electroencephalography [44, 50]. a. Gamma Waves - Gamma waves are linked to the acquisition of new information in the brain. b. Beta Waves - Beta waves are frequently related to this style of thinking. When we focus our attention on cognitive and real-world tasks, they take over our typical conscious state. c. Alpha Waves - Alpha waves are associated with calm and pleasant thinking. Mental coordination, relaxation, and alertness, as well as alertness and relaxation, are all aided by them. The Alpha state, also known as the resting state of the brain, is the default mode of the brain. d. Theta Waves - Theta waves are most common during sleep, although they can also be found in deep meditation. e. Delta Waves - Delta waves are characterised by their low frequency , which is associated with perfect tranquillity and relaxation. Dreams are formed when one is in the deepest of meditations and sleep [45]. Figure 1. Comparison of EEG Bands [21] 3. Electrooculography - In terms of accuracy and reliability , the EOG headband's sensor is not quite up to the task. Sometimes the EOG headband's sensor will continue to report blink strength levels even when there has been no blink. Unfortunate as that may be for some,

and reliability , the EOG headband's sensor is not quite up to the task. Sometimes the EOG headband's sensor will continue to report blink strength levels even when there has been no blink. Unfortunate as that may be for some, it's important to accept that current Brain Computer Interfaces are far from perfect and still in the developmental stages. [9]
Figure 2. EOG signal. Saccades, blinks , overshoots and pursuit movements[23]. II. L

There are many different types of wheelchairs on the market, each of which is defined by its power source. The two most prevalent types of wheelchairs are manual wheelchairs and electric wheelchairs. The first is the standard wheelchair , which is used by the vast majority of persons with disabilities. In general, the chair has two large wheels that allow it to travel forward, backward, left, and right. To move the chair forward, we must push both wheels ahead, and to move the chair backward, we must push both wheels backward. Turning left requires pushing on the left side, while turning right requires pushing on the right side.[39,40] A Joystick Controlled Wheelchair is the second most used wheelchair in the market after the manual wheelchair . The joystick directs the motorised wheelchair in the direction indicated by the user. The faster the joystick is pushed, the faster the electric wheelchair will travel. When you let go of the joystick, the brakes are applied automatically . The motorised wheelchair will then come to a complete stop.Individuals who are unable to utilise a joystick may be able to use non-proportional controls.[41, 46] A. Limitations of Manual Wheelchair 1. You need to rely on someone to push the chair . 2. Due to the fact that these models are manual wheelchairs, those who

a joystick may be able to use non-proportional controls.[41, 46] A. Limitations of Manual Wheelchair 1. You need to rely on someone to push the chair . 2. Due to the fact that these models are manual wheelchairs, those who lack the necessary upper body strength to manage a wheelchair may struggle to go great distances. 3. We have to move the wheels with our limbs because it is a manual wheelchair , they might cause repetitive strain injuries, particularly in the shoulders .[ 27,31] 4. Going on a 5cm or larger curb can be difficult in manual wheelchairs since going on an elevation with manal force can cause the wheelchair to flip upside down.[34] B. Limitations of Powered Wheelchair 1. This chair offers so many advantages, and the price is the most important consideration. They are more expensive when compared to manual wheelchairs. However , it is unquestionably an excellent investment.[42,43] 2. As the manual wheelchair is lighter in weight, powered wheelchairs are significantly heavier than manual wheelchairs. 3. They are difficult to transport – you may require a customised vehicle. 4. You’ll have to be conscious of power usage. 5. Maintenance and repairs are necessary to ensure optimum functionality of the device [28,33]. C. Objective of The Research This research intends to develop an enhanced wheelchair (Cognitive Chair)

customised vehicle. 4. You’ll have to be conscious of power usage. 5. Maintenance and repairs are necessary to ensure optimum functionality of the device [28,33]. C. Objective of The Research This research intends to develop an enhanced wheelchair (Cognitive Chair) using Brain Sensing Technology to assist paralysed and disabled persons using a Brain Sensing Headband. Electro-oculography will collect data from our brain and transfer it to a mobile application, which will send it to the wheelchair , which will operate in accordance with our Neuro Signal [26,38].

Manual wheelchairs and electrically powered wheelchairs (controlled by joystick) are both limited to paraplegic people because quadriplegic people won’t be able to control them on their own due to all four limbs dysfunction whereas the proposed wheelchair can be used by people suffering from both paraplegia as well as quadriplegia[24, 25, 47, 48]. Table 1 : Comparison of the Proposed model with other papers and existing models Models/ Features Model 1 [35] Model 2 [36] Model 3 [37] Proposed Model (Cognitiv e-Chair) Brain Computer Interface (BCI) YES NO YES YES Electroencephal ography (EEG) YES NO YES YES Electrooculogra phy (EOG) YES YES NO YES Camera NO YES NO NO Automatic Braking System NO NO NO YES Obstacle Avoiding System NO NO NO YES Voice Recognition NO NO NO YES On the basis of the comparison table, these existing technologies have limitations, which brings the proposed paradigm into play. The proposed model has certain distinctive features, such as an Automatic braking system and Obstacle Avoiding System [32]. A. Obstacle Avoidance System If a wheelchair encounters an impediment on its path, it will automatically detour from its path to avoid colliding with the impediment and will be rerouted to its intended destination [29]. B. Automatic Braking System In case of an unavoidable obstruction or if the driver panics, the Automatic Braking System

will automatically detour from its path to avoid colliding with the impediment and will be rerouted to its intended destination [29]. B. Automatic Braking System In case of an unavoidable obstruction or if the driver panics, the Automatic Braking System will apply the brakes automatically . Even if the headband and mobile device are disconnected, or if the headband is removed from the passenger's scalp, the system will immediately apply brakes [30]. For this reason, we can suggest that the proposed model can play a vital role in the lives of the intended audience. And it can be a revolutionary advancement as the technology is still partially discovered and not known to many people. IV. P

In figure 3, a headset attached to a mobile application serves as the control mechanism for an EEG/EOG-based control system. Electrodes in the headgear transmit the data to mobile applications. Furthermore, the application performs the algorithm and is linked to a microcontroller that controls the wheelchair's movement. The EEG/EOG-based system is typically made up of five major
signal accession, signal initialisation, feature uprooting, classification, and an action that controls the wheelchair's motors. The

signals are acquired using the headset electrodes in the signal accession block. Because the majority of electrodes are positioned in the frontal cortex, upper face gestures are the most reliable warnings to detect in our system. The

input signals are refining and scaling in the signal initialisation unit before being transmitted to the feature uprooting block. The basic features are uprooted and transmitted to the classification system in this block. The classification block interprets the incoming signals and generates the control instructions. These control commands are thereafter sent to the wheelchair's automobiles.
based control system Figure 4, illustrates the system flow of the proposed model. The significant components of this proposed model

EEG or EOG headband for brainwave and blink detection, bluetooth module (HC-06) for wireless transmission of signals, an android application that acts as a data receptor and transmitter , an arduino microcontroller to process the data from the Android application into wheelchair motors and other necessary hardware. The above devices work together to give a person control of their wheelchair using just their mind and eye blinking. Figure 4. Brain Controlled System project flow V. P

In this model we propose a systematic implementation plan which includes the hardware devices, software and development of an Android Application. A. Hardware 1. EEG headband( Electroencephalography )- Electroencephalography (EEG) is a technique for recording the electrical activities of the brain that involves inserting electrodes on the erson’'s scalp. It typically detects the voltage changes within the brain's neurons. Previously , it was primarily employed by medical organisations, but this technology is currently being used in a variety of other industries. The electrodes of EEG headbands record brain wave patterns, which are subsequently sent to a computer or any other cloud service platform [16]. 2. EOG headband (Electrooculography)- The cornea-positive standing potential relative to the rear of the eye is measured by EOG. The potential can be measured by having the patient travel a certain distance after placing skin electrodes outside the eye near the lateral and medial canthus. It basically investigates abnormalities of the retina's outermost layer , the retinal pigment epithelium, by recording the eye whenever a voltage differential between the cornea and the retina may be observed. These bioelectrical impulses are often low in amplitude, necessitating the use of an amplifier to accurately record the EOG. [12].

3. Microcontroller- Microcontrollers are very small computers on a single integrated circuit that have a processor , a memory module, and programmable input and output codes. They are commonly employed in embedded systems that have unique and dedicated purposes.[18]. 4. Bluetooth module- Bluetooth modules are used to connect to smartphones. Whereas smartphones necessitate the use of a Bluetooth terminal application for data transmission and reception. It manages the wireless network's communication channel clearly and without any form of delay .[17]. 5. Motor driver- The motor driver enables the control of DC motors by converting the microcontroller's low current output into a greater current suited for motor control.[15]. 6. DC motors- A direct current (DC) motor is a sort of electric machine that transfers electrical energy into mechanical energy . It accepts direct current and turns it into mechanical rotations. [14]. 7. GPS module- The position of a GPS receiver is calculated by timing the signal sent by GPS satellites. The control segment, space segment, and user segment are the three key parts that make up the GPS module's operation. The accurate and reliable operation of the entire system is dependent on the proper operation of each of these parts.[13]. 8. Accelerometer- It's a tool for determining proper acceleration. The acceleration of a body in its own instantaneous rest frame is

accurate and reliable operation of the entire system is dependent on the proper operation of each of these parts.[13]. 8. Accelerometer- It's a tool for determining proper acceleration. The acceleration of a body in its own instantaneous rest frame is known as proper acceleration [11]. 9. Sharp sensor- For precise distance measurement, a sharp sensor is commonly utilised. It is a type of infrared sensor that performs substantially better [10]. 10. Gyroscope- A gyroscope sensor is a tool that uses the gravitational pull of the earth to determine its orientation. A gyroscope is a device that measures the rotation of the earth's axis. It can determine the article's slant and horizontal direction, whereas an accelerometer can only measure straight movement [7]. 11. Speedometer- The speedometer sensor is located in the vehicle's transmission and is used to track the rotational speed of the driveshaft. The sensor sends this information to the vehicle's PC via the speedometer link, which converts an electrical pulse into a numerical speed. In the end, the figure appears on the speedometer and tells you exactly how fast you're travelling [6]. B. Software 1. Android Studio - Android Studio is an integrated development environment (IDE) for creating Android applications, tablets, and wearables, among other things. It can be downloaded for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux operating systems.

you're travelling [6]. B. Software 1. Android Studio - Android Studio is an integrated development environment (IDE) for creating Android applications, tablets, and wearables, among other things. It can be downloaded for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux operating systems. Some of the best features of Android Studio are

● Fast Emulator ● Help to Connect Data with Firebase ● Supports Kotlin ● Help to Build Up App for All Devices C. Android Application An Android Application will be constructed from android studio to process the data from the EEG or EOG headband, which will then transmit the data to the bluetooth module, which will then be delivered to the microcontroller via bluetooth to the system [5]. D. Proposed flowchart
Figure 5. Working algorithm VI. C

We have been able to produce a detailed blueprint of the model that we have offered. Prototypes will be created in the very near future as a means of validating and substantiating our claims. Studies have shown that EEG controlled wheelchairs are 92.1% accurate[19], while EOG controlled wheelchairs are considered 99% accurate [20]. Once the prototype development is complete, we'll do an extended research on the model based on the findings of real-world testing. People suffering from paraplegia and quadriplegia as well as their family members can benefit from such systems in the future by being independent of the helping hand, leading to a better post disorder life. This kind of model can be built for old persons or those with good functional limbs but unable to walk for an extended period of time, which can be utilised in their everyday life for hassle-free conveyance, with necessary upgradations in certain aspects. text: The present invention relates to the field of a face recognit ion system, and more specifically, to a face recognition system using a convolutional neural network (CNN) and a recurrent neural network (RNN). The intelligent face recognition system using deep recurrent neura l network includes a set of sensors to sense one or more attributes associated with a face of a person, a face image acquisition module operatively coupled to the set of sensors, for key generation formed of a convolutional neural network (CNN) and a recurrent neural network (RNN) for outputtin g a co nsistent key value by using sample facial images of a person, a database for storing facial record, an individual’s credential to access t he database, a storage unit that facilitates machine -readable medium storing instruction that, when executed by the at least one processing unit, a processing unit configure to retrieving data from a database and recognize the face, a communication module to communicate data regarding face recognition . No. of Pages : 16 No. of Claims : 6
Rudra Joshi +61466988797 ◇rudrajoshi.cs@gmail.com ◇Sydney, New South Wales, 2146, Australia ◇LinkedIn ◇GitHub
